docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey health investigators have been unable to pinpoint the source of E. coli bacteria that fatally poisoned a 20-month-old boy from Parsippany this week, officials said yesterday. The baby, Nicolaus Brayton, died Tuesday of hemolytic uremic syndrome, or H.U.S., a rare and virulent effect of E. coli infection that causes severe diarrhea, inflammation of the blood vessels and kidney failure, said Dennis McGowan, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Health and Senior Services.

headline.main: Officials Unable to Identify Source of Deadly Bacteria

docs.abstract: New Jersey health investigators are unable to pinpoint source of E coli bacteria that caused death of Parsippany toddler, Nicolaus Brayton; child's parents and twin sister also suffered gastrointestinal sickness after eating in unidentified restaurant, but are recovering (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Novartis A.G., one of the world's leading agricultural biotechnology companies, acknowledged yesterday that it had eliminated genetically engineered ingredients from all of its food products. The policy was disclosed in a letter sent by a company official to the environmental group Greenpeace and later confirmed by the company. Novartis, which makes Ovaltine, Gerber baby foods, Wasa crackers and various health foods, said in the letter that it had basically achieved its goal by June 30.

headline.main: Novartis Ended Use of Gene-Altered Foods

docs.abstract: Novartis AG, one of world's leading agricultural biotechnology companies, acknowledges that it has eliminated genetically engineered ingredients from all of its food products; policy is disclosed in letter to environmental group Greenpeace (S)
